title: Muscular Dystrophy (Adult)
scope: ** Evaluation and management of muscular dystrophies presenting in adults or diagnosed in adulthood. Covers FSHD, LGMD subtypes, Becker MD, OPMD, Emery-Dreifuss MD, and distal myopathies. Includes diagnostic workup (genetic testing, muscle biopsy), cardiac and respiratory monitoring, symptomatic management, and emerging gene therapies. Excludes myotonic dystrophy (covered separately) and pediatric-onset Duchenne MD (though includes adult Becker MD).

Core Labs (All Patients).rationale: Elevated in muscular dystrophies; degree varies by subtype (very high in BMD/LGMD, mildly elevated in FSHD/OPMD)
Renal function (rhabdomyolysis risk); electrolytes; LFTs (may be elevated from muscle source, not hepatic)
Core Labs (All Patients).target: Normal; note ALT/AST may be elevated from muscle

Core Labs (All Patients).rationale: Elevated in inflammatory and dystrophic myopathies; may be more sensitive than CK in some dystrophies

Extended Labs.rationale: Definitive diagnosis; >30 LGMD genes; dystrophin gene for BMD; D4Z4 for FSHD; PABPN1 for OPMD
Becker MD diagnosis; large deletions (60-70%) detected by MLPA; sequencing for point mutations
FSHD1: contraction of D4Z4 repeats on chromosome 4q35 (1-10 repeats on permissive 4qA allele)
FSHD2: SMCHD1 mutations with D4Z4 hypomethylation on permissive allele
OPMD: GCN expansion (>8 repeats vs normal 6)
Emery-Dreifuss: emerin (X-linked) or lamin A/C (AD/AR) mutations; cardiac risk stratification

Extended Labs.item: Myositis antibody panel (if inflammatory myopathy in differential)
Extended Labs.rationale: Differentiate inflammatory from dystrophic myopathy; includes Jo-1, Mi-2, SRP, HMGCR
Cardiac involvement assessment; may be chronically mildly elevated in dystrophies
Extended Labs.target: Normal (<0.04 ng/mL); chronically elevated in some dystrophies

Rare/Specialized.rationale: When genetic testing is inconclusive; dystrophin staining (BMD: reduced), sarcoglycan panel (LGMD), merosin (LGMD R23)
Rare/Specialized.target: Normal staining; reduced/absent specific protein directs genetic testing

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Undiagnosed muscular dystrophy after targeted gene panels; novel gene discovery
Pattern of fatty infiltration helps differentiate MD subtypes; guides biopsy site

Essential Studies.timing: Characterize myopathic vs neurogenic pattern; guides further workup
Essential Studies.target: Myopathic pattern: short-duration, low-amplitude, polyphasic MUPs; early recruitment; no spontaneous activity (or minimal)

Essential Studies.timing: ALL patients with muscular dystrophy; cardiomyopathy screening (especially BMD, EDMD, LGMD)
Essential Studies.target: Normal LV function (EF >55%); no wall motion abnormalities; no dilation

Essential Studies.item: Pulmonary function tests (FVC, FEV1, MIP, MEP) (CPT 94010)
Essential Studies.timing: Respiratory muscle involvement; restrictive pattern; guide ventilation decisions
Essential Studies.target: FVC >80% predicted; MIP more negative than -60 cmH2O

Essential Studies.timing: Conduction abnormalities; arrhythmia; EDMD and LMNA carriers at high risk of sudden cardiac death
Essential Studies.target: Normal sinus rhythm; normal PR, QRS, QTc intervals

Extended Studies.timing: Gold standard for detecting myocardial fibrosis (late gadolinium enhancement); more sensitive than echo for early cardiomyopathy
Extended Studies.target: No late gadolinium enhancement; normal EF; no fibrosis

Extended Studies.timing: Arrhythmia detection; EDMD and LMNA carriers especially; AV block, atrial fibrillation
Extended Studies.target: Normal rhythm; no high-grade conduction disease

Extended Studies.timing: Nocturnal hypoventilation; sleep-disordered breathing; guide NIV initiation
Extended Studies.target: Normal overnight O2 saturation (>95%); no significant desaturations

Extended Studies.timing: Subtype differentiation by pattern of fatty infiltration; FSHD: periscapular + hamstring; LGMD variable
Extended Studies.target: No fatty infiltration; specific patterns guide diagnosis

Rare/Specialized.timing: OPMD: dysphagia quantification; aspiration risk assessment
Rare/Specialized.target: Normal swallow; no aspiration or penetration

Rare/Specialized.timing: OPMD: pharyngeal dysfunction characterization; surgical planning (cricopharyngeal myotomy)
Osteoporosis from reduced weight-bearing and if on corticosteroids

Acute/Emergent.indication: Acute respiratory failure from respiratory muscle weakness; FVC <50% or acute decompensation

dosing.instructions: IPAP 10-16 cmH2O, EPAP 4-6 cmH2O; titrate to comfort and SpO2 >92%; may need 24-hr support in acute setting

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Inability to protect airway; facial trauma preventing mask seal; pneumothorax
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: SpO2; ABG; respiratory rate; patient comfort; CO2 levels; mask fit

Acute/Emergent.indication: Rhabdomyolysis prevention/treatment if CK markedly elevated (>5x ULN) or acute renal injury

dosing.instructions: 1-2 L NS bolus; target urine output >200 mL/hr if rhabdomyolysis; alkalinize urine if CK >10,000

Acute/Emergent.monitoring: CK; renal function; urine output; myoglobinuria

Cardiac Management.indication: Cardiomyopathy prevention/treatment; ACE inhibitor for LV dysfunction in BMD, LGMD, EDMD

dosing.instructions: Start 2.5-5 mg daily; titrate to 10-20 mg daily; initiate at first sign of LV dysfunction or prophylactically in high-risk dystrophies (BMD)

Cardiac Management.contraindications: Bilateral renal artery stenosis; pregnancy; angioedema history; hyperkalemia
Cardiac Management.monitoring: BP; K+; renal function; cough; EF on echo

Cardiac Management.indication: Heart failure from cardiomyopathy; beta-blocker for LV dysfunction

dosing.instructions: Start 3.125 mg BID; double dose q2wk as tolerated; max 25 mg BID; take with food

Cardiac Management.contraindications: Severe bradycardia; 2nd/3rd degree AV block; decompensated HF; severe asthma
Cardiac Management.monitoring: HR; BP; fatigue; fluid retention; EF

Cardiac Management.indication: EDMD and LMNA mutations: prophylactic ICD/pacemaker for conduction defects; high risk of sudden cardiac death even with normal EF

dosing.instructions: LMNA mutation carriers: prophylactic ICD/pacemaker per HRS guidelines; do NOT wait for symptomatic bradycardia; BMD cardiomyopathy: ICD per standard heart failure criteria

Cardiac Management.monitoring: Device checks q6-12 months; rhythm monitoring; lead integrity

Symptomatic and Supportive.indication: Nocturnal hypoventilation; FVC <50% predicted or symptomatic nocturnal hypoxemia

dosing.instructions: IPAP 12-18, EPAP 4-6 cmH2O; titrate per polysomnography; start when FVC <50% or earlier if symptomatic; assess compliance

Symptomatic and Supportive.contraindications: Inability to use mask; untreated pneumothorax
Symptomatic and Supportive.monitoring: Overnight oximetry; ABG or cap gas q6-12mo; mask comfort and compliance

Symptomatic and Supportive.indication: Pain from musculoskeletal sources; contractures; neuropathic component

dosing.instructions: Start 300 mg qHS; titrate by 300 mg q1-3d; target 300-600 mg TID; max 3600 mg/day

Symptomatic and Supportive.monitoring: Sedation; dizziness; respiratory depression (caution in respiratory compromise)

dosing.instructions: 500-1000 mg q6h as needed; max 3000 mg/day (2000 mg/day in elderly or hepatic impairment)
Start 5 mg TID; increase by 5 mg/dose q3d; max 80 mg/day divided TID-QID; taper to discontinue (do NOT stop abruptly)

Symptomatic and Supportive.contraindications: Abrupt withdrawal (seizures, hallucinations); severe renal impairment
Symptomatic and Supportive.monitoring: Sedation; weakness (may unmask underlying weakness); respiratory depression

dosing.instructions: Start 2 mg qHS; may increase by 2-4 mg q6-8h; max 36 mg/day

Symptomatic and Supportive.contraindications: Concurrent CYP1A2 inhibitors (ciprofloxacin, fluvoxamine); hepatic impairment
Symptomatic and Supportive.monitoring: LFTs at baseline, 1 month, 3 months; sedation; hypotension; dry mouth

dosing.instructions: Start 100 mg every morning; may increase to 200 mg daily; avoid afternoon dosing

Symptomatic and Supportive.contraindications: Hypersensitivity; cardiac arrhythmia; left ventricular hypertrophy
Symptomatic and Supportive.monitoring: Headache; insomnia; cardiac monitoring if history; BP

Symptomatic and Supportive.indication: Depression; anxiety related to chronic progressive disease (ALTERNATIVE to duloxetine — do NOT combine; serotonin syndrome risk)

dosing.instructions: Start 25 mg daily; increase by 25-50 mg q1-2 weeks; max 200 mg/day

Symptomatic and Supportive.contraindications: Concurrent MAOIs; concurrent duloxetine (serotonin syndrome); caution with QT-prolonging drugs
Symptomatic and Supportive.monitoring: Suicidality (first weeks); GI upset; sexual dysfunction; hyponatremia; serotonin syndrome if combined with other serotonergic agents

Symptomatic and Supportive.indication: Depression with comorbid pain; neuropathic pain component (ALTERNATIVE to sertraline — do NOT combine; serotonin syndrome risk)

dosing.instructions: Start 30 mg daily x 1-2 weeks; increase to 60 mg daily; max 120 mg/day

Symptomatic and Supportive.contraindications: Severe hepatic impairment; concurrent MAOIs; concurrent sertraline (serotonin syndrome); uncontrolled narrow-angle glaucoma
Symptomatic and Supportive.monitoring: LFTs; BP; nausea (take with food); serotonin syndrome if combined with other serotonergic agents

Symptomatic and Supportive.indication: Urinary urgency and frequency from neurogenic bladder dysfunction

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg BID-TID; max 5 mg QID; extended-release 5-30 mg daily preferred

Symptomatic and Supportive.contraindications: Uncontrolled narrow-angle glaucoma; urinary retention; GI obstruction
Symptomatic and Supportive.monitoring: Dry mouth; cognitive effects (especially elderly); constipation; urinary retention

Symptomatic and Supportive.indication: Overactive bladder (alternative to anticholinergics; fewer cognitive effects)

dosing.instructions: Start 25 mg daily; may increase to 50 mg daily
Start 5 mg TID; max 10 mg TID; short-term use (2-3 weeks); avoid in elderly

Symptomatic and Supportive.contraindications: Concurrent MAOIs; recent MI; arrhythmia; heart failure; hyperthyroidism
Symptomatic and Supportive.monitoring: Sedation; dry mouth; dizziness; anticholinergic effects

Symptomatic and Supportive.indication: Insomnia; sleep disturbance common in chronic neuromuscular disease

dosing.instructions: 3-5 mg PO 30-60 min before bedtime; max 10 mg

Disease-Specific Therapies.indication: Corticosteroid for ambulatory Duchenne/Becker patients (limited evidence for adult BMD specifically); slows loss of ambulation

dosing.instructions: 0.9 mg/kg/day; evidence strongest in Duchenne; limited data in adult BMD but may be considered; take with food

Disease-Specific Therapies.pretreatment: Bone density; BP; glucose; vaccination status
Disease-Specific Therapies.contraindications: Active infection; uncontrolled diabetes; systemic fungal infection
Disease-Specific Therapies.monitoring: Weight; bone density; blood glucose; BP; cataracts; adrenal function

Disease-Specific Therapies.indication: Alternative corticosteroid for dystrophinopathies when deflazacort unavailable; slows decline in muscle function

dosing.instructions: 0.75 mg/kg every other day; alternate-day dosing reduces side effects; taper if discontinuing

Disease-Specific Therapies.pretreatment: Bone density; BP; glucose; vaccination status
Disease-Specific Therapies.contraindications: Active infection; uncontrolled diabetes; GI ulceration
Disease-Specific Therapies.monitoring: Weight; bone density; blood glucose; BP; cataracts; adrenal function

Disease-Specific Therapies.indication: OPMD with disabling dysphagia; cricopharyngeal muscle dysfunction causing obstruction

dosing.instructions: Surgical section of cricopharyngeal muscle; performed by ENT/head-neck surgeon; improves swallowing in 80-90% of OPMD patients

Disease-Specific Therapies.pretreatment: Swallowing study confirming cricopharyngeal dysfunction; anesthesia risk assessment
Disease-Specific Therapies.contraindications: Active aspiration pneumonia; poor surgical candidate; severe respiratory compromise
Disease-Specific Therapies.monitoring: Swallowing assessment post-procedure; aspiration monitoring; wound healing

Disease-Specific Therapies.indication: FSHD with severe scapular winging limiting arm elevation; failure of conservative management

dosing.instructions: Scapulothoracic fusion or scapulopexy; improves overhead arm function in selected FSHD patients; requires adequate deltoid strength

Disease-Specific Therapies.pretreatment: Adequate deltoid function confirmed; respiratory risk assessment; orthopedic evaluation
Disease-Specific Therapies.contraindications: Poor surgical candidate; inadequate deltoid function; severe respiratory compromise
Disease-Specific Therapies.monitoring: Post-operative ROM; shoulder function assessment; wound healing

Disease-Specific Therapies.indication: Emerging therapies for specific dystrophy subtypes (LGMD R9/FKRP, LGMD R2/dysferlin, FSHD); currently investigational

dosing.instructions: Refer eligible patients to registries (clinicaltrials.gov); AAV-based gene replacement for sarcoglycanopathies and dysferlinopathies under investigation

Disease-Specific Therapies.monitoring: Trial-specific adverse events; immune response to AAV vector

Referrals & Consults.item: Neuromuscular specialist for diagnostic confirmation, genetic testing interpretation, and long-term management
Cardiology for echocardiogram, Holter, cardiac MRI, and cardiomyopathy management; electrophysiology referral for EDMD/LMNA carriers
Pulmonology for PFT interpretation, NIV initiation and titration, and respiratory failure management
Respiratory therapy for BiPAP setup and titration, cough assist training, and secretion management
Genetic counseling for inheritance pattern discussion, family screening, and reproductive planning
Physical therapy for stretching, contracture prevention, submaximal strengthening, and mobility optimization
Occupational therapy for ADL adaptation, upper extremity function, and assistive technology evaluation
Speech therapy for OPMD dysphagia assessment, swallowing strategies, and communication support
Nutrition/Dietitian for caloric needs assessment, weight management, and dietary modification for dysphagia
Orthopedic surgery for scoliosis management, contracture release, and scapular fixation (FSHD)
Social work for disability services, insurance navigation, MDA resources, and caregiver support
Palliative care for goals of care discussion and advance care planning in progressive disease

Patient Instructions.item: Carry a medical alert card or bracelet stating muscular dystrophy diagnosis and AVOID SUCCINYLCHOLINE for all anesthesia encounters
Return to ED immediately for acute shortness of breath, inability to lie flat, or marked respiratory distress — may indicate acute respiratory failure requiring emergent ventilatory support
Report new shortness of breath (especially lying down), morning headaches, or excessive daytime sleepiness — may indicate respiratory muscle deterioration needing ventilation support
Report palpitations, dizziness, or fainting episodes — may indicate cardiac conduction disease or cardiomyopathy requiring urgent evaluation
Report worsening swallowing difficulty or choking episodes (OPMD patients) — aspiration risk assessment needed
Report dark or cola-colored urine after exercise or illness — may indicate rhabdomyolysis requiring IV hydration
Maintain regular follow-up with cardiology and pulmonology even if asymptomatic — cardiac and respiratory complications may be silent
Inform ALL healthcare providers (surgeons, anesthesiologists, dentists) of muscular dystrophy diagnosis before any procedure requiring sedation or anesthesia

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Regular low-impact aerobic exercise (swimming, recumbent cycling) as tolerated to maintain cardiovascular fitness; avoid eccentric/high-resistance exercise which may worsen muscle damage
Stretching program to prevent and manage contractures; daily range-of-motion exercises for all joints
Maintain healthy weight: obesity worsens mobility and respiratory function; underweight/sarcopenia worsens weakness
Fall prevention measures: grab bars, non-slip surfaces, assistive devices; home safety evaluation
Annual influenza and pneumococcal vaccination; COVID-19 vaccination per guidelines to prevent respiratory infections
Aspiration precautions for OPMD patients: upright positioning during meals; thickened liquids as recommended by speech therapy

differential.features: Subacute onset; may have skin rash (DM); elevated CK; responds to immunosuppression (except IBM); autoantibodies present
differential.tests: Myositis antibody panel; muscle biopsy (inflammatory infiltrate); MRI (edema vs fatty infiltration); response to steroids

differential.features: Myotonia (delayed relaxation); distal weakness; cataracts; cardiac conduction defects; characteristic facies; DMPK/CNBP genetic testing
differential.tests: Genetic testing (CTG repeat in DM1; CCTG in DM2); EMG (myotonic discharges); clinical exam (grip myotonia)

differential.features: Proximal weakness without CK elevation (or mild); lower motor neuron pattern on EMG; SMN1 deletion
differential.tests: SMN1 gene deletion testing; EMG (neurogenic not myopathic); CK normal/mildly elevated

differential.features: Exercise intolerance; episodic rhabdomyolysis; specific enzyme deficiencies
differential.tests: GAA enzyme activity (Pompe); muscle biopsy (glycogen/lipid storage); ischemic forearm test; genetic testing

differential.features: Fatigable weakness; fluctuating; ptosis and diplopia common; no CK elevation
differential.tests: AChR or MuSK antibodies; RNS/SFEMG; edrophonium test; normal CK

differential.features: Proximal weakness with elevated CK; hypothyroid symptoms; reversible with treatment
differential.tests: TSH (elevated); Free T4 (low); symptoms resolve with thyroid replacement

differential.features: Proximal weakness with CK elevation in setting of statin use; anti-HMGCR antibodies in immune-mediated necrotizing myopathy
differential.tests: Statin history; anti-HMGCR antibodies; improvement with statin discontinuation (unless immune-mediated)

evidence.recommendation: Cardiac screening recommended for all muscular dystrophy patients
LMNA mutation carriers: prophylactic ICD reduces sudden cardiac death risk
evidence.source: [Meune C et al. J Am Coll Cardiol 2006](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/17236468/)

evidence.recommendation: ACE inhibitors delay cardiomyopathy progression in Becker MD
evidence.source: [Duboc D et al. J Am Coll Cardiol 2005](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/15766818/)

evidence.recommendation: NIV improves survival in neuromuscular respiratory failure
Avoid succinylcholine in all muscular dystrophies (hyperkalemic arrest risk)
evidence.source: [Hayes J et al. Br J Anaesth 2008](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/18344556/)

evidence.recommendation: FSHD genetic diagnosis: D4Z4 contraction on 4qA allele
Cricopharyngeal myotomy improves swallowing in OPMD

monitoring.action: Initiate/optimize ACE inhibitor and beta-blocker; cardiology referral; cardiac MRI
EP evaluation; ICD/pacemaker consideration for LMNA; antiarrhythmics
Initiate NIV if FVC <50% or symptomatic; pulmonology referral

monitoring.frequency: Annually if FVC <80%; or if symptoms of nocturnal hypoventilation
monitoring.action: Initiate nocturnal BiPAP; formal sleep study
Hydration; renal monitoring if markedly elevated
Diet modification; speech therapy; consider cricopharyngeal myotomy
PT reassessment; assistive device prescription; wheelchair evaluation if needed

monitoring.frequency: Q2 years; annually if on steroids
monitoring.action: Calcium, vitamin D supplementation; bisphosphonate if osteoporosis

disposition.criteria: Stable respiratory function; no acute cardiac arrhythmia; no rhabdomyolysis; outpatient neuromuscular follow-up arranged
Acute respiratory decompensation requiring NIV; rhabdomyolysis with CK >10x ULN; new cardiac arrhythmia; aspiration pneumonia; new diagnosis requiring expedited workup
Respiratory failure requiring intubation or continuous NIV; cardiac arrhythmia requiring monitoring/intervention; severe rhabdomyolysis with AKI; perioperative monitoring
All patients: q6-12 months; more frequently if declining; genetic counseling if new diagnosis
Annually minimum for all dystrophy patients; q3-6 months if cardiomyopathy or respiratory involvement
